awd_titl_txt: Identifying Deeply Conserved Patterns of Epigenetic Modification and Imprinting during Seed Development
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF National Plant Genome Initiative Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2018. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow who also presents a plan to broaden participation in biology. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to Dr. Rebecca Povilus is "Identifying Deeply Conserved Patterns of Epigenetic Modification and Imprinting during Seed Development". The host institution for the fellowship is the Whitehead Institute for Biomedical Research and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Mary Gehring.

Seeds are important for humans; seeds make up most of our diets and are a key part of the ecosystems that we depend on. Understanding what factors influence seed development is necessary to improve seed crops (such as wheat, corn, rice, and soybean), as well as to ensure the production of viable offspring when re-introducing genetic diversity into inbred crop varieties. Only recently have technologies and systems been available to elucidate the role that epigenetic modifications (chemical changes to DNA bases and to associated DNA-packaging proteins) play during plant reproduction. While epigenetic modifications have been shown to be important for seed development in a small number of distantly related plant species, the actual patterns and effects of epigenetic modification appear to vary substantially between species. To predict how broadly epigenome-based technologies for crop improvement and plant breeding can be applied, the patterns of epigenetic modifications that are fundamental to all flowering plants, or are specific to particular lineages must be determined. This project will provide an otherwise lacking foundation for understanding how the role that epigenetic processes play during reproduction has evolved across flowering plants. To do so, epigenetic modifications and their association with gene expression during seed development will be identified in the emerging model system Nymphaea thermarum, a member of one of the most ancient flowering plant lineages. Training objectives include genomics, epigenomics and bioinformatics. Broader impacts include outreach to local school teachers through the Whitehead Partner program and the development and distribution of a module for early-science education that explores the importance of biodiversity and basic research to agriculture and food security. This module will be presented as part of the Arnold Arboretum Summer Institute, and will be available at https://nthermarum.weebly.com/.

The goal of this project is to understand epigenetic modification and its impact on gene expression during seed development. Specific objectives include 1) determining the dynamics of epigenetic modification during reproductive development in N. thermarum through immunolocalization of methylated DNA and histone marks, methylation-sensitive DNA sequencing and chromatin profiling and 2) identifying genes that are maternally- or paternally-imprinted during early embryo and endosperm development using hybrid crosses and tissue specific gene expression analysis. By comparing results from Nymphaea to information from model species, deeply conserved patterns of epigenetic modifications and imprinted gene expression will be distinguished from those that are derived within either monocots (such cereal crops) or eudicots (such as Arabidopsis). Results of this project will be published on open-access pre-print servers and peer-reviewed journals, and information will be available on the website https://nthermarum.weebly.com/.

Keywords: seed development, embryo, endosperm, epigenetics, Nymphaea, comparative genomics and epigenomics

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This fellowship project characterized epigenetic modifications and imprinted gene expression in an experimentally tractable member of one of the earliest-diverging angiosperm lineages (Nymphaea thermarum, Nymphaeales). Results were compared to information from other flowering plants, thereby identifying patterns of DNA/histone methylation and imprinting that are deeply conserved among flowering plants. Understanding which patterns are fundamental to flowering plant reproduction, or are specific to particular lineages, is necessary to predict how broadly epigenome-based technologies for crop improvement and plant breeding can be applied

Importantly, this work included publication/dissemination of genomic and gene expression resources for a group of flowering plants that has long been under-represented during research. Nymphaea thermarum, the world?s smallest water lily, is a member one of the ANA-grade lineages of flowering plants, which diverged early in the evolutionary history of flowering plants and are sister to the vast majority of flowering plant diversity. These lineages provide important perspective for any investigations of flowering plant evolution, and yet have few genomic/genetic or experimental resources available. The resources generated and disseminated with support of this fellowship are therefore relevant to not just research on seed development and epigenetics, but also more broadly to phylogenetics/genomics, and studies of gene family evolution across land plants.

This project has produced genome assemblies and annotations, as well as records of seed tissue-specific gene expression and genome-wide DNA methylation, for two species of water lily (Nymphaea thermarum and N. minuta). These species are uniquely experimentally tractable (small size, short generation time, relatively small genomes), compared to other water lily species or other groups of plants that have similarly interesting evolutionary relationships to other flowering plants. Therefore, the development of genetic/genomic resources represents an important step for further developing these species as 'model systems' for experimental genetics, as well as other applications like phylogenetics/genomics or studies of gene family evolution across flowering plants.

The tissue-specific datasets produced by this project were designed to address questions about the evolution of epigenetic modifications and genetic imprinting (parent-of-origin effects on allele expression). The results have generated hypotheses about the evolution of these phenomena, which point to the interconnected evolution of several seed traits, such as epigenetic regulation of gene expression, effective or absolute maternal:paternal gene/genome dosage, and seed structure, that ultimately impact nutrient dynamics during seed development. These hypotheses can now be tested by future research into the vast diversity of reproduction and seeds in flowering plants. Furthermore, this project generated lists of candidate genes that provide an explicit roadmap for additional research into gene function during seed development in Nymphaea or other flowering plant species. Understanding the evolution of seed development is crucial because seeds represent the cornerstones of human diets and agriculture; by studying patterns of conservation or diversity during seed development, we can develop new strategies for crop improvement or breeding.

The fellowship project also supported outreach activities and products, including the development of an undergraduate-level course on how conflicts shape the development, genetics, and molecular biology of plants. The course syllabus and teach materials are available through https://rpovilus.weebly.com/teaching.html. In addition, work supported by the project has been featured in multi-media webpages and videos that communicate the importance of preserving and exploring biodiversity during basic research. These resources are publically available through the Whitehead Institute: ?Unusual Labmates? series https://wi.mit.edu/series/unusual-labmates, ?Nature?s library: the value of biodiversity to biological research? https://youtu.be/vsuZNrd2QuM). The fellowship also supported participation in a program that brought together scientists and students/teachers from around the great Boston-metro area to discuss current topics in science and give students the chance to visit research labs virtually or in-person and take part in hands-on learning activities.
